actual: justice irwin delmore davidson, whose career on the bench, in the new york state assembly and in the house of representatives spanned some 40 years, died yesterday of cancer in his home at premium point in new rochelle, n.y. he was 75 years old.   justice davidson, who served in the assembly from 1937 until 1948, introduced the first slum-clearance bill in new york and wrote rentcontrol, workmen's compensation and civil-rights legislation.   he was named to the court of special sessions in 1948 and occupied that position until 1954, when he was elected united states representative from manhattan's west side on the democratic-liberal ticket.   he vacated his house seat after serving one term and was elected judge of the court of general sessions in 1956.  in that post, he presided over the trial in 1958 of seven teen-age gang members for the killing of michael farmer, a 15-year-old polio victim. when he sentenced four of the youths to prison terms ranging from five years to life, judge davidson said that he imposed the penalties with a heavy heart.

actual: gardner cowles jr., founder and publisher of look magazine and head of one branch of a family communications empire that included newspapers, magazines, book publishing and television stations, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at southampton (l.i.) hospital.   mr. cowles, who had long suffered from cancer, was 82 years old and had homes in manhattan, southampton, and florida.   a liberal republican and internationalist, he was for many years an influential voice in urging the united states to move away from isolationism and toward a more active role in world affairs.   in 1942 he accompanied wendell l. willkie on the journey around the world that inspired the latter's book ''one world,'' which helped to win republican support for the wartime policies of president franklin d. roosevelt. later mr. cowles championed such causes as american recognition of china's communist government.

actual: lead: when franz kafka was readying ''the metamorphosis'' for publication, he implored his editor not to allow pictures of gregor samsa's transformation into a cockroach. they came dressed as clowns, monsters, zombies and donald trump for the annual two-legged bit of aerobic nonsense known as the bay to breakers. running in a bernie sanders wig was richard gould of novato. all race bags, unlike all race candidates, must be transparent. at the finish line, the winners and the tens of thousands of runners behind them were fully entitled to receive shiny finisher’s medals, energy bars, freebies, loud music and all the bananas they could consume on the premises. there were 40,000 registered runners and thousands more freeloaders. officers arrested seven people, five of them for public intoxication. also in the mix were t-shirted members of something called “team f— it up,” a rubik’s cube, an ersatz golden state warriors starting five, a woman wearing a t-shirt that said “sometimes i open my mouth and my mother comes out,” along with any number of batmen, supermen and spider-men. steve trutane, 51, ran his fifth straight bay to breakers while barefoot. he said it builds foot strength, and no one disagreed. said he was dressed as a homicidal clown, whatever that might be. they ran inside of cardboard boxes designed to look like their own coffins. “death doesn’t always have to be morbid,” said kajima. “ running alongside him were 24 friends, dressed as sheep. chronicle staff writer brandon mercer contributed to this report. email srubenstein@sfchronicle.com, esernoffsky@sfchronicle.com
actual: the costumed participants in the race, so-called, were heavy this year on all things scary, such as political candidates.  “i have an unusual sense of humor,” said john seumptewa, who was wearing an orange-blond trump wig and waiting for the starting gun.  the early arrivals for the race, which has attracted 1.8 million runners since it began in 1912, negotiated a maze of steel barricades, outhouses, homeless folks in doorways, cops, guards and more outhouses.  runners were bound by race rule 142 (“competitors must wear clothing that is clean, designed and worn so as not to be objectionable”) although it was not clear how that applied to a zombie with spikes coming out of his head.  [...] that was the case because isaac mukundi of grand prairie, texas, crossed the finish line with a time of 35 minutes and 23 seconds, exactly one second ahead of second-place finisher tsegay tuemay weldlibanos of tampa, fla.  at the finish line, the winners and the tens of thousands of runners behind them were fully entitled to receive shiny finisher’s medals, energy bars, freebies, loud music and all the bananas they could consume on the premises.  while fleet of foot, the 2016 winners were well off the course record set in 2009 by the legendary sammy kitwara of kenya who crossed the finish line in 33 minutes and 31 seconds without benefit of an outhouse.  in the side streets of the south of market area were waiting hordes of unregistered runners who traditionally slip into the passing throng and run for free, dodging course marshals along the way who are empowered to kick them out.  other course marshals were watching for folks relieving themselves without the benefit of an outhouse, another iconic element of the race despite the “no public urination” signs.  cops tucked away in strategic spots monitored the passing runners to make sure that the stuff they were hydrating with was the stuff they were supposed to be hydrating with.  officers arrested seven people, five of them for public intoxication.  jim guida and his brother, ralph, were running as movie icons the blues brothers.  dennis bott was hulk hogan (“he gets people excited”), and john hearney ran with a basketball hoop on his head that strangers kept trying to dunk various items into, to his growing annoyance.  [...] in the mix were t-shirted members of something called “team f— it up,” a rubik’s cube, an ersatz golden state warriors starting five, a woman wearing a t-shirt that said “sometimes i open my mouth and my mother comes out,” along with any number of batmen, supermen and spider-men.  halfway through the course, on the fabled, fearsome hayes street hill,  the extra weight from all the heavy costumes was making their owners work twice as hard as their fellow runners in lycra.  a dozen people carried a 20-foot-long star destoyer spaceship from the “star wars” film franchise.  instead of blasting out laser weapons, it blasted out dance music, attracting hordes of other runners who danced beside the space ship as they ran.

(writing by stephen brown; editing by angus macswan)
actual: rome (reuters) - italian prime minister silvio berlusconi is launching legal actions against media in italy and abroad, including britain, france and spain, for libel in their coverage of his private life,

actual: for wgbh radio host brian o’donovan, growing up in ireland during the 1960s and ’70s, christmas shone a like a warm beacon of light over those dark social and economic times.  “i believe strongly that christmastime gives us a license to be sentimental in ways we’d hold ourselves back from at other times of the year, and music is a great way to express that,” said o’donovan. in 2003, he launched his own holiday concert, “a christmas celtic sojourn.” returning this year for its 11th season, o’donovan and music director seamus egan will be joined by a world-class lineup of celtic musicians, singers, and dancers. to get us in the spirit, o’donovan shared a list of his favorite holiday albums of all time.

actual: the american rush to retirement is apparently beginning to subside.  under the pressure of inflation, the number of people claiming social security benefits for the first time, which has risen almost every year since the program was founded in the new deal era, has begun to taper off.   by about 1985, this index of the rate at which elderly people are leaving the work force could begin to drop if the trend of the last decade continues. about 1.6 million people now retire each year.

actual: newark the new united states attorney for new jersey, the son of a state senator and one-time candidate for governor, promises to step up the government's fight against organized crime and political corruption.   he is w. hunt dumont, whose father is senator wayne dumont jr., republican of phillipsburg.  ''the public fails to recognize that the mob would be out of business if it were not for their political connections,'' mr. dumont said at his recent swearing-in ceremony, adding that many people were aware of some of the activities of organized crime.   he said that the acceptance of bribes by public officials, thus violating their public trust, ''is a vice that cannot and will not be tolerated.''

actual: what with the holidays and vacation, it's taken us until now to clean out all the political papers that accumulated during the 1980 campaign - a process that discloses an anniversary.   it was just a year ago that six republican candidates mounted a des moines stage for the first nationally televised event of the campaign, the iowa debate. that snowy saturday night seems long gone, irrelevcant: ronald reagan didn't even participate. and yet one wonders, leafing through the ragged old notes and clippings, is it?

actual: jerusalem four years since anwar el-sadat journeyed to jerusalem, israelis are having difficulty recalling the exhilaration of that time. the joy has faded into apprehension. the peace process the egyptian leader initiated - still the region's solitary structure of accord - seems a flimsy shelter of sanity, requiring zealous and passionate protection.   israel, soon to play its last card of concession under the treaty with egypt by completing its withdrawal from sinai, is frantically defending that vulnerable peace. after the assassination of president sadat, after senate approval of the awacs sale to saudi arabia, after the reagan administration's approving noises about saudi crown prince fahd's peace plan - which demands five israeli compromises but offers no explicit arab guarantees in return - the threshold of alarm here has fallen to a dangerous low. the government of menachem begin points an angry finger at every utterance that fails to fit the intricate provisions of the camp david accords, while israelis inside and outside the government mutter darkly about reconsidering the sinai withdrawal, mandated for april.   black and frantic moods tend to rise quickly in this region and then pass. but they can do damage. if anxious impulse replaces calculation in this crucial period, conflicts are waiting to flare.

prediction: dona guimaraes's article ''landmarks for rent in britain'' (travel section, nov. we arrived just after christmas, following a 12-day voyage in a 35-ship convoy. wightwick manor is not far from stratford-on-avon, a propinquity that enabled us to walk the roads that shakespeare once trod. every enlisted man in the battalion emerged from his nissen hut shouldering the straw-filled mattress cover that had been his bedding, carried it up to the highest hill of the manor, and lined up behind fellow g.i. only then did the mission of a somewhat mysterious stranger who had arrived earlier at our headquarters become evident.
actual: to the editor:   dona guimaraes's article ''landmarks for rent in britain'' (travel section, nov. 16) was of special interest to me since i spent 10 weeks rent-free in 1944-45 in a house she mentioned, wightwick manor, near wolverhampton.   i was one of 550 other nontourists, members of the 747th field artillery battalion, united states army, lieut. col. john a. mcewan commanding. we arrived just after christmas, following a 12-day voyage in a 35-ship convoy.

actual: commodity prices tumbled broadly yesterday as traders sold off their holdings on the assumption that lower interest rates were still some distance away.   significant declines were posted in metals, grains, livestock and financial instruments. moving counter to the trend were orange juice, cotton and heating oil, which was lifted sharply by uncertainty over how tension in the middle east might affect oil supplies, analysts said.

actual: produced several years ago for britain's granada television, ''the christians'' is now getting a showcase in this country. this 13-part series will be carried, beginning tonight, on wor-tv on mondays at 8 o'clock. the programs, written and narrated by bamber gascoigne, trace the history of christianity from the birth of christ through the holy roman empire and the questionings of modern science, to the state, albeit dated, of the church in 20th-century russia, poland and italy.   mr. gascoigne, educated at eton, cambridge and yale, is a british television personality in addition to having been a drama critic for several publications. he has written, among other books, ''world theater'' and ''treasures and dynasties of china.'' in ''the christians,'' made in more than 30 countries, he carefully avoids polemics and any hint of proselytizing to concentrate on a fairly dispassionate history of how christianity came to exert such enormous influence on all aspects of the world as we know it.

actual: doctors have reported their first success in using an experimental antibody treatment to achieve a long-lasting remission of b-cell lymphoma, an uncommon type of cancer.   the researchers said that monoclonal antibodies, a form of the disease-fighting proteins produced by white blood cells, were ''remarkably effective'' in halting an advanced case of the disease in a 67-year-old man. the cancer attacks antibody-producing cells, weakening the body's natural disease-fighting system.

actual: problems in mortgage refinancing have become a threat to the future of new york city's rental housing, according to real estate experts.  mortgages generally made for 10-year terms are coming due on existing properties, and they must be renewed at much higher rates.  in many cases lenders want most of the principal repaid when the loan is renewed - and in a few cases paid off entirely.   ''we're in serious trouble,'' said jack e. sonnenblick, chairman of the sonnenblick-goldman corporation, a mortgage brokerage concern. ''the fellow who has a loan of one or two million dollars coming due and the bank wants 18 percent - the owner has no choice. in some cases there's not enough income.'' the only long-term solution is cooperative conversion, he said.   all income-producing properties, whether they are office buildings, shopping centers or residential dwellings, need access to mortgage financing on a continuing basis if they are to thrive as investments for their owners and usable shelters for their occupants. the different forms of property compete for the available capital, as real estate itself competes for capital with other forms of investment.

actual: ossining in 1825, inmates from new york's first state prison were barged down the hudson river from auburn to begin work on their new home here. they quarried local limestone and built on the edge of the river the first cell block for what was to become the state's second prison.   the gray stone building, its windows sealed in disuse, still stands next to the conrail right-of-way, a reminder of the days when the ossining correctional facility was known as sing-sing prison.   the intervening years brought notoriety to this community whose lights used to flicker when the switch was pulled on the electric chair in death row. the chair itself was sent to green haven prison in dutchess county about five years ago, but ossining's ''up-theriver'' reputation remains, and there are those here who have always wished the prison would go away.

actual: whenever the seventh avenue train races between 86th and 96th streets and offers a fleeting, darkened glimpse of what looks like latter-day catacombs, the question invariably arises: what is it? from the windows of the broadway local the ghost of this stone age grotto, suddenly illumined by the speeding train, is a place only dante or kafka might have imagined. the walls are begrimed with thick 1970's-style graffiti while something resembling a platform, strewn with debris, stands in the ashen dimness of places most cities would rather forget about.    but we stare all the same, until springing into view like painted letters on the hull of a sunken liner are the tell-tale faded mosaics spelling a station's name: 91st street. the name appears again on a higher panel, framed by terra-cotta molding with golden numerals in relief, a combination typical of the cartouche created by heins & lafarge, the firm originally commissioned to design subway ceramics.

prediction: burrowing in and devoting days to d & d dishes, as glamorous new york friends used to describe their ''difficult and demanding'' cook-offs, has rarely seemed so appealing, so necessary. and not necessarily to produce a dauntingly d & d menu. a new way to cook (artisan, $40) isn't billed as a one-book cooking course for the new decade, even though it can serve as one. sally schneider has a vivid sense of flavor, perhaps resulting from her long experience as both a chef and a food stylist. elisabeth luard, an english writer (and friend) who travels to remote cookstoves with an anthropologist's zeal, offers a lovely hodgepodge of holiday food rituals from around the globe, connecting them first to the agricultural calendar and then to mythology and religion. but she has directly observed many far-flung rituals, and these accounts are the best: the day of the dead in a mountain village near mexico city in the early 1960's, traveling in andalusia with her children via mule cart on a rollicking post-easter pilgrimage to the shrine of the virgin of the dew.
actual: burrowing in and devoting days to d & d dishes, as glamorous new york friends used to describe their ''difficult and demanding'' cook-offs, has rarely seemed so appealing, so necessary. of course, this year's cookbooks were planned and written long before sticking close to home and hearth was mandated, but they provide plenty of pleasant ways to do just that -- and, as usual, plenty of ways to roam the globe by reading, marketing and then hunkering down at the stove. and not necessarily to produce a dauntingly d & d menu.    for primeval comfort, it's either chocolate or mashed potatoes. there's not much chocolate in one potato, two potato (houghton mifflin, $35), but there are plenty of mashed potatoes -- and baked-potato skins and hash and fries of all kinds and potato pancakes and even the french forebear of tater tots. everything you could want from a potato, really, with a startling lack of contrivance, given that the book features 300 recipes for potato dishes. there's nothing fancy or pioneering here, even if one of the authors, roy finamore, has edited many of the country's most stylish and accomplished cooks (including martha stewart and diana kennedy) and his co-author, molly stevens, has classic french training. just terrific recipes and tips. it's hard to think of anything more comforting or satisfying than the potato-leek soup with bacon and chunky potatoes, borrowed from gramercy tavern's tom colicchio, or a fat sausage surrounded by warm potato salad. (if you must have chocolate, there's a dense and moist farmhouse chocolate cake, made with mashed potatoes, and a recipe for chocolate coconut macaroons that's a deliciously shameless variation on almond joy candy bars -- with a secret ingredient you'll guess.)

actual: about six hours before the kentucky derby was run today, a bugle sounded at churchill downs for the first race and a roar resounded among the early arrivals of the 141,009 people who annually congregate for america's most famous horse race. hearing the bugle call, one horseplayer smiled at another. actual: archibald macleish, distinguished poet, playwright, statesman and man of letters, died last night at massachusetts general hospital in boston, which he entered march 20 for treatment of an undisclosed illness. he was 89 years old and had lived in conway, mass.   few american writers achieved the occupational diversity that mr.  macleish did. he was a soldier, lawyer, magazine editor, librarian of congress, director of the office of facts and figures, assistant secretary of state for cultural affairs; a founder of the united nations educational, scientific and cultural organization; harvard professor, television dramatist and gentleman farmer. above all, though, he was a poet, who drew his themes from the large social and political issues of the day as well as from the more private emotions of daily life. it was an achievement recognized by three pulitzer prizes and the presidential medal of freedom. his latest book, a collection of letters edited by r.h. winnick, will be published this summer by houghton mifflin.

actual: the individual who accepts the conventional wisdom may feel threatened in holding a mere handful of stocks but will do it anyway to make a big profit. that's a conclusion of thomas e. conine jr. and maurry tamarkin who seek to explain why many individuals do not diversify but concentrate on two to four stocks.   dr. conine has a ph.d. in finance from new york university and is associate professor of finance at fairfield university in connecticut. dr. tamarkin has a ph.d. in finance from washington university, st. louis, and is associated with clark university in worcester, mass.   dr. conine said in a telephone interview that investors have generally been told to diversify for safety - spread capital among 10 to 15 holdings.

prediction: british director ken loach tackles a subject right in line with his familiar social consciousness in “jimmy’s hall,” the fact-based story of a rural, activist-minded maverick who runs afoul of the system in 1930s ireland. gralton is barely in his mam’s cottage door when a number of the locals, particularly the youth, begin urging him to reopen a liberal cultural center he’d founded in the years before he left. most of all, they were encouraged to be free thinkers. a scene of the two sharing a chastely romantic dance is a delicately lighted standout. you might wish the film had been more willing to trade authentic peripheral faces for the polish brought by, say, andrew scott (moriarty on the bbc’s “sherlock”) as a young priest unafraid to question sheridan’s views.
actual: “jimmy’s hall” movie review: director ken loach tackles a subject in line with his familiar social consciousness in the fact-based story of jimmy gralton (barry ward), a rural, activist-minded maverick who runs afoul of the system in 1930s ireland.
